objects.name: Ruinous Ursa
objects.description:
Beginning on Jan. 14, 2022, reports began emerging about a series of attacks targeting numerous Ukrainian government websites. As a result of these attacks, numerous government websites were found to be either defaced or inaccessible. As a result of this, the government of [Ukraine formally accused Russia](https://thehackernews.com/2022/01/ukrainian-government-officially-accuses.html) of masterminding these attacks against their websites. 

A day later, public reporting outlined a new malware family, called [WhisperGate](https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/01/15/destructive-malware-targeting-ukrainian-organizations/), that originally was observed on Jan. 13, 2022. This malware family disables Windows Defender Threat Protection, is destructive in nature and was discovered to target multiple organizations in Ukraine. Microsoft has publicly attributed the use of this custom malware family to a threat actor they refer to as DEV-0586. Unit 42 refers to this threat actor as Ruinous Ursa.

objects.name: WhisperGate malware targeting Ukraine
objects.description: First observed by Microsoft on Jan. 13, 2022, the WhisperGate malware family is computer network attack (CNA) malware aimed at deleting Microsoft Windows Defender and corrupting files on the target. It consists of two samples: One appears as ransomware while the other is a beaconing implant used to deliver an in-memory Microsoft Intermediate Language (MSIL) payload. The in-memory code uses Living Off the Land Binaries (LOLBINs) to evade detection and also performs anti-analysis techniques, as it will fail to detonate when certain monitoring tools exist. At the time of writing, there are two known samples identified as WhisperGate: Stage1.exe and Stage2.exe. Stage1.exe purports to be ransomware, as it overwrites the target’s master boot record with 512 bytes and upon reboot displays a ransomware note.

At the time of writing, there are two known samples identified as WhisperGate: Stage1.exe and Stage2.exe. Stage1.exe purports to be ransomware, as it overwrites the target’s master boot record with 512 bytes and upon reboot displays a ransomware note.
